Discussions and interpretations 415
The origin of copper deposits has sparkled theories and genetic models that seek 416
to explain the different processes for a wide variety of native copper deposits in host 417
rocks such as basic and ultrabasic igneous rocks, sedimentary rocks and also in sulphide 418
deposits. In the Paraná volcanic province, controversy was generated centered in at least 419
three theories about the origin of native copper based on magmatic, late-magmatic, and 420
hydrothermal models. The magmatic origin suggested by Mello (2000) was based in the 421
native copper mineralization at the surface of cooling joints (Água Perdida region, 422
18
Paraná). According to the author the temperature of cooling joint formation was 750 ºC 423
and at this temperature a residual and immiscible fluid, rich in copper, migrated to this 424
space generating a native copper mineralization with timing correlated to the lava 425
solidification processes. The late-magmatic origin indicated by Szubert et al. (1979) 426
suggests that the native copper mineralization (Itapiranga region, Santa Catarina) in the 427
microfractures and in the core of basaltic flows originated from late-magmatic processes 428
(hydrothermal processes included but not detailed). The hydrothermal origin indicated 429
by Pinto et al. (2011b) and Arena et al. (2014) is supported in the present study. 430
Regarding the magmatic origin, it is worth noting that the magmatic processes 431
are conditioned to high-temperatures so the native copper crystallization occurs in 432
equilibrium with the magma. In deposits at this temperature, copper isotopes show 433
? 65Cu ratios ~ 0‰ and no significant fractionation (Markl et al. 2006). The isotopic 434
composition of native copper crystals in ultramafic rocks (Albarede 2004; Ikehata and 435
Hirata 2012) shows ? 65Cu values between -0.03 ‰ and 0.14 ‰ supporting the absence 436
of significant copper fractionation during magmatic, high-temperature processes, thus 437
higher values than 0.3 ‰ cannot be expected in these temperatures. In this case, the 438
copper mineralization in the Paraná volcanic province should have ?65Cu values close to 439
0 ‰ but this is not the case, they are more fractionated and must have been modified 440
during the formation of mineralization. 441
The study carried out by Cabral and Beaudoin (2007) in the Quebec 442
Appalachians (Canada) suggest the occurrence of native copper crystals of magmatic 443
origin. According to that study, the native copper occurs as inclusions (~ 50 µm in 444
length) in feldspars and the authors present an S versus As diagram from the high-445
temperature native copper from Quebec, Canada, and the low-temperature native copper 446
deposits from the Keweenaw volcanic province, Michigan. The comparison highlights 447
19
the electron probe analyses that show the high concentrations of sulfur and arsenic in 448
the high-temperature native copper from Québec and the low concentrations of sulfur 449
and arsenic in the low-temperature native copper from Michigan. In the Paraná 450
province, the host volcanic flows of copper mineralization have essentially mantle 451
origin according copper contents versus rare earth elements correlations. In the same 452
way, the EPMA analyses in the copper native crystals shows very low sulfur content 453
(0.03 wt. %) and is accompanied by contents of arsenic below the electron microprobe 454
detection limit, similarly to the low-temperature copper mineralization of Michigan. A 455
careful search for native copper inclusions was made by backscattered electrons images 456
in the primary minerals of the host basalt. However no evidence of magmatic copper 457
crystals associated with the primary minerals was observed. This observation requires 458
further detail. The native copper mineralization on the surface of the cooling joint in the 459
basalts of the Paraná volcanic province acts as a time marker. Surface cracking (e.g. 460
Kilauea volcano) according to Peck and Minakami (1968) starts at 900 ºC, but the 461
cooling joint is formation completed when the bulk of the flow (e.g. Big Lost River 462
flow, USA) reaches around 750ºC (Lore et al. 2000). The structure is only completed 463
when all magmatic processes come to an end and the volcanic rock is consolidated. The 464
copper mineralization in the Paraná volcanic province was generated after the formation 465
of the cooling joints. In addition, the native copper occurs associated with a low 466
temperature mineral assemblage. Other evidence can be seen in the host basalts where 467
the native copper is associated with smectite and also in cavities where the rounded 468
massive copper occurs in the core, associated with zeolites and/or calcite in the rim. 469
Accordingly, the native copper origin in the Paraná volcanic province is not compatible 470
with magmatic processes. The hydrothermal hypothesis for the copper origin in the 471
20
Parana volcanic province can explain the mineralization based on the evidence 472
presented in this study. 473
The Cretaceous native copper mineralization in the study area can be compared 474
with the Proterozoic mineralization of native copper from Keweenaw Province, USA, 475
and also with the Upper Permian mineralization of native copper from Emeishan 476
volcanic province in China. In the Keweenaw Province, the native copper deposits are 477
hosted at the top of rift subaerial basaltic lava (Bornhorst and Barron 2011). Also, fluid 478
inclusion studies (Livnat, 1983) indicated that the hydrothermal fluids at 150-200 ºC 479
crossed the underlying sedimentary sequence (conglomerates) and the volcanic pile to 480
deposit the native copper. In the Emeishan province, the hosting volcanic rocks (basalts, 481
breccias and tuffs) with bitumen have Cu average contents of 200 ppm (Li et al. 2005) 482
and are interbedded with carbonaceous sedimentary rocks. The native copper 483
mineralization is hosted in the breccias, in the amygdaloidal crust and also in the 484
sedimentary sequence at the top of the basalt flows. In places, the copper replaces and 485
fills bitumenous fissures in the basaltic rock. The minerals are characterized by a low-486
temperature assemblage of laumontite, epidote and quartz and the hydrothermal 487
mineralization is epigenetic (Li et al. 2005). In the Paraná volcanic province, the H1, H2 488
and H3 hydrothermal events were identified, defined and described by Hartmann et al. 489
(2008, 2012a, 2012b). These events were triggered by boiling water and its vapour from 490
the Guarani aquifer that migrated upwards into the volcanic pile and promoted alteration 491
in the host basalts, zeolites deposition and native copper mineralization in cooling 492
joints, fractures and cavities. 493
The description of hydrothermal processes in the Paraná volcanic province 494
requires an evaluation of the copper source that generated the mineralization. In the 495
Michigan district, one of the discussions that have permeated this issue for over a 496
21
hundred years is the presence of copper in the crystal structure of iron minerals 497
(magnetite) in the host basalts, its chemical changes and the concentration of copper 498
(e.g., Butler and Burbank 1929). The study performed by Cornwall (1956) in the 499
Michigan native copper describes the presence of copper in magnetite (200 – 800 ppm), 500
ilmenite (90 – 300 ppm), clinopyroxene (51 – 320 ppm) and plagioclase (20 – 73 ppm). 501
In the Paraná volcanic province some studies (e.g. Tazaki et al. 1988; Arioli 2008; Pinto 502
et al. 2011b) have also suggested the presence of copper in magnetite. 503
The LA-ICPMS analyses in this study show that the minerals of the host basalt 504
contain copper, mainly magnetite. This finding contributes to a better understanding of 505
the behavior of copper during the hydrothermal events. The chemical reactions triggered 506
by the boiling water from the Guarani aquifer in the host basalts promoted the alteration 507
of magnetite-hematite to clay minerals and released the copper from its crystal lattice. 508
The hydrothermal fluids leached the copper and promote the first concentration in the 509
clay minerals (smectites). As the hydrothermal activity was developing, copper was 510
being deposited along the cooling joints that served as a pressure relief for hydrothermal 511
fluids. Similarly, the copper mineralization was generated in the cavities in the 512
amygdaloidal crust. Studies in monophase fluid inclusions in amethyst deposits (Gilg et 513
al. 2003; Duarte et al. 2009; Morteani et al. 2010; Juchem 2014) showed that the 514
evolved boiling fluids had low salinity and temperatures up to 150 ºC, although Gilg et 515
al. (2014) determined the additional presence of high-salinity fluids. The presence of 516
heulandite identified by Raman spectroscopy and calcite means that the copper 517
mineralogical association has been formed at temperatures lower than 200 °C (Carr et 518
al. 1999). These temperatures are consistent with those indicated by Pinto et al (2011b) 519
to the copper mineralization in the Vista Alegre mining district (100 – 150 ºC) Paraná 520
22
volcanic province and also for the hydrothermal alteration assembly (smectites, zeolites, 521
quartz and calcite). 522
Au and Ag contents are present both in host basalts and in the native copper 523
crystals, but also show no clear correlation between them in the copper mineralization 524
of Paraná volcanic province. The experimental hydrothermal mechanisms for gold and 525
silver (transport and concentration) in epithermal systems (Cole and Drumond 1986; 526
Williams-Jones and Heinrich 2005) are based on pressures and temperatures which 527
coexist with boiling liquid-vapor phases. The model predicts that the vapor transport 528
capacity of metal is greater than that of hot water. This explosive mechanism was 529
indicated by Arena et al. (2014) for the leaching, transport and mineralization of copper, 530
gold and silver in the Realeza region, Paraná volcanic province. At a temperature of 150 531
°C, the vapor carrying metal can mix with groundwater that is close to the surface and 532
form metal mineralization as mentioned by Williams-Jones and Heinrich (2005). 533
Similar mechanism occurred in the copper mineralization along the Paraná volcanic 534
province. The Cretaceous hydrothermal boiling fluids with copper percolated through 535
the cooling joints and fractures and formed the native copper mineralization. 536
The process of forming copper deposits trigger many fractionation mechanisms 537
that are not fully understood. Several studies (e.g., Zhu et al. 2000; Larson et al. 2003; 538
Markl et al. 2006) suggest that these mechanisms are influenced by redox reactions, 539
valence of copper ions, speciation in solution and in some cases organic process. In 540
hydrothermal deposits the most significant mechanisms are liquid-vapor separation, 541
multi-step equilibrium processes and physical/chemical parameters (temperature, 542
oxygen fugacity, pH and salinity of the fluid). These processes leave their marks as 543
fingerprints in the copper isotope ratios which can be used to define the origin of the 544
deposits (Maréchal et al. 1999; Dekov et al. 2013; Zhang et al. 2013) and also to 545
23
distinguish high from low-temperature processes. The Cu isotope fractionation 546
(sulfides) in hydrothermal systems (Graham et al. 2004) is associated with the process 547
of Cu leaching and by the ore-bearing fluid. The isotope fractionation is differentiated 548
for hydrothermal vapor and for fluid phase. Multiple mineralization events could occur 549
from a fluid with different Cu isotopic composition, oxygen/sulfur fugacity, temperature 550
and chemical composition. In the copper hydrothermal deposits hosted in basalts 551
(Larson et al. 2003) the copper isotopic values are more similar to the mantle (~ 0 ‰), 552
and overlap the values of chalcopyrite in mafic intrusions with isotope variation extends 553
to higher values. 554
In the supergene environments the redox processes affect strongly the copper 555
isotopic compositions (Larson et al. 2003; Maher 2005; Markl et al. 2006; Mathur et al. 556
2012) and represents varied and repetitive fractionation processes (leaching, oxidation 557
and reduction) controlled by changes in the water system over time (Maher, 2005). 558
However, extremely high fractionation (9 ‰) may reflect an open system or kinetic 559
fractionation (Sherman, 2013). The variation in ?65Cu (Maher, 2005) of supergene 560
deposits involves three processes, the leaching of copper from existing minerals, the 561
change in the valence of copper and the precipitation of copper mineral. The degree of 562
leaching of 65Cu in the copper precursor mineral defines the final isotope ratios. 563
Supergene copper minerals co-existing in the same sample can be isotopically heavier 564
than the copper precursor mineral (Asael et al. 2007), but the low-temperature 565
fractionation (Maréchal and Sheppard, 2002) can precipitate minerals isotopically 566
lighter than the fluid. The supergene enrichment displays oxidized secondary phases 567
(e.g., cuprite) with isotopic ratios higher than native copper. The ?65Cu variation in the 568
supergene native copper deposits range between -3.03 ‰ (Maréchal et al. 1999) to 0.72 569
‰ (Larson et al. 2003) and up to 1.26 ‰ (Larson et al. 2003) when associated with 570
24
cuprite. These variations overlap the isotope ratios from Michigan native copper 571
hydrothermal deposits (Larson et al. 2003; Maher 2005). 572
In the Paraná volcanic province the hydrothermal system with boiling fluids 573
(water and its vapour) generated a wide mineralization of native copper. The ?65Cu 574
ratios variations in the native copper was interpreted as isotopic fractionation reactions 575
during the H1, H2 and H3 (Hartmann et al., 2008, 2012a, 2012b) low-temperature 576
hydrothermal events and by the supergene environment that affected the native copper 577
mineralization. The succession of hydrothermal events, added to redox reactions in the 578
exposed volcanic flows at the surface ensured the formation of the secondary co-579
existing copper minerals with native copper as precursor mineral and is supported by 580
the values of ?65Cu from 0.3 ‰ up to 1.89 ‰. Similarly local variations occur in several 581
places of the province. In the sample JS4 the isotope ratios of 0.65 ‰ and 1.07 ‰ show 582
the fractionation of two different events of hydrothermal native copper mineralization. 583
The cuprite in this sample shows an isotope variation in the core (~ 0.18 ‰) with more 584
fractionated ?65Cu (up to 0.73 ‰) in the rim. In the same region, in sample JS3, was 585
observed chrysocolla with lighter isotope ratios (~ 0.31 ‰). In the regions of Dom 586
Pedro de Alcantara (FS86a, b), Santo Augusto (JS4a, c), Taquaruçu do Sul (PD1a, b) 587
and Cascavel (CP14a, b) the variation of isotope ratios reflect multiple hydrothermal 588
mineralization with different times of copper leaching and fractionation along the fluid 589
flow pathway. Different degrees of leaching and stronger fractionation of the Cu 590
isotopes (W247, P1C) in the supergene environment were observed in the Frederico 591
Westphalen (RS), and Francisco Beltrão (PR) regions. Accordingly, in the Paraná 592
volcanic province the origin of the copper is hydrothermal. Multiple copper 593
mineralization process occurs with leaching and mineral precipitation along the time 594
and different fractionation of copper and isotope ratio variation. 595
25
596
Conclusions 597
Hydrothermal native copper mineralization is widespread in the Paraná volcanic 598
province as dendrides and needles in the cooling joints, fractures and also filling 599
cavities in the amygdaloidal crust. Apart from native copper, other mineral phases such 600
as cuprite, tenorite, chrysocolla, malachite and azurite make up the copper 601
mineralization. 602
The origin of copper in the Paraná volcanic province is associated with the 603
magma that rose from the mantle to the surface and formed the basaltic flows. The 604
copper was added in the crystal lattice of the basalt forming minerals. As a 605
consequence, the copper content average in the host basalts is 207 ppm. The Cretaceous 606
H1, H2 and H3 (Hartmann et al., 2008, 2012a, 2012b) hydrothermal events altered the 607
volcanic rocks. The minerals most affected by the hydrothermal alteration were 608
magnetite, ilmenite, clinopyroxenes and the microcrystalline matrix. From this process 609
smectites were formed. Copper, silver and gold were released from the crystal structure 610
of igneous minerals. The copper initially was concentrated in the smectites. The 611
transport of copper was supported by boiling water and vapor at temperature of 100 - 612
150 °C. The native copper was deposited along the network path crossed by the 613
hydrothermal fluid in the cooling joints, fractures and within the vesicles of 614
amygdaloidal crust. The variations of isotope ratios reflect Cu-mineralization pulses that 615
occurred during the hydrothermal and supergene events. This study thus makes a major 616
contribution to the understanding of the hydrothermal origin of the native copper 617
mineralization in the large Paraná volcanic province. Of particular significance is the 618
multianalytical approach in the study, with emphasis on copper isotopes. 619

ABSTRACT 31
A new frontier of amethyst geode deposits (amethyst, agate, gypsum, calcite and 32
zeolites) driven by the prospective guides termed silica gossan may change the 33
metallogenetic scenario previously known in the Paraná volcanic province, Brazil. The 34
silica gossans are present throughout the province and occur in basalt, basaltic andesite 35
and rhyodacite. In this study, we focus on the Ametista do Sul mining district, Rio 36
Grande do Sul, Brazil, the largest producer of amethyst geodes in the world (400 37
t/month). Veia Alta flow is the main amethyst producer in the district. A silica gossan 38
occurs in the Coogamai flow above the Mina do Museu, at the top of the mineralized 39
flow. The Coogamai is a basalt (47.87 wt. % SiO2) with columnar jointing, 40
intermediate-Ti Paranapanema magma type (2.25 wt.% TiO2 and Ti/Y = 416.2). The 41
prospective guide displays polygonal shape associated with increase of clay minerals at 42
the surface, concentration of iron oxides and the presence of silicified sandstones, in 43
addition to marshes with ponds; a change in color (ocher to brownish) at the surface and 44
the vegetation type are observed. The gamma spectrometry survey (counts per second) 45
at Mina do Museu silica gossan shows negative anomalies in %K, eU and eTh above 46
the amethyst deposits, with values of 55 cps outside silica gossan and 43 cps within the 47
silica gossan. These anomalies are associated with a combination of factors that began 48
in the hydrothermal events and ended with the weathering of the silica gossans. The 49
bulk rock analyses within the silica gossan show values of loss on ignition up to 1.8 50
3
wt.% while outside the silica gossan this value is around 0.5 wt.%. SiO2, K2O, MgO, 51
CaO and Na2O display negative correlation with loss on ignition. X-ray diffraction 52
identified the presence of montmorillonite and kaolinite in the soil of the silica gossan. 53
EMPA in the bulk rock of Coogamai flow identified dioctaehdral and trioctahedral 54
interlayered smectite. Mg-smectite is present in the samples within silica gossan while 55
K-smectite is present outside silica gossan. 56
57
1. Introduction 58
The Ametista do Sul mining district in the Serra Geral Group, Paraná volcanic 59
province, is located in the northwest portion of Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil (Fig. 1) 60
and has the largest amethyst geode deposits in the world, with a production of 400 61
t/month (Silva, 2010) . Silica gossans occur above all known deposits in the district and 62
are an important prospective guide for the discovery of new deposits. 63
The classification of gossans is usually referred to deposits of metallic minerals 64
(Pirajno, 2009; Scott, 2001) generated in a sulphide-rich environment and characterized 65
by high concentrations of iron, silica and intense colors. In a specific way, the volcanic 66
rocks of the province were generated in an intraplate environment, with low sulfur 67
contents. This situation is unprecedented, because little information is available in the 68
scientific literature on the occurrence of gossans in other similar volcanic provinces. 69
Gossans were described for the first time in the southern portion of the Paraná province 70
by Pertille et al. (2013) in Quaraí (Brazil) and Artigas (Uruguay) mining districts. The 71
term silica gossan (Baggio et al., 2014) is used based on the similar characteristics of 72
the gossans related to sulphides and in the silicification of the sand layers brought from 73
Botucatu formation by the hydrothermal events. The Botucatu formation is Jurassic-74
Cretaceous aeolian sandstone (dune fields) from Paraná sedimentary basin which was 75
4
covered by lava flows of Paraná volcanic province and currently belongs to the Guarani 76
aquifer system. Previous studies (Keller and Hanson, 1968; Sayin, 2007) used the term 77
silica gossan to define hydrothermal prospective guides for kaolin. 78
The origin of silica gossans in the province is associated with unique geological 79
features in the province. The large extension of the Botucatu Formation was covered by 80
lava flows with internal structure of type I massive cores (Gomes, 1996) and thickness 81
between 10 and 30 m that provided the transformation of a sand desert into one of the 82
largest confined aquifers in the world: the Guarani aquifer. The Cretaceous volcanism 83
was the heat source to boil the water from the Guarani aquifer and generate the H1, H2 84
and H3 hydrothermal events (Hartmann, 2008; Hartmann et al., 2010). These events 85
altered the volcanic pile and triggered the formation of sandstone sills and dikes, basalt-86
sandstone breccia, amethyst epigenetic deposits and the intense silicification along the 87
chimneys where the hydrothermal fluids percolated. The silica gossans have their origin 88
associated with these hydrothermal events, and their structure was highlighted at the 89
surface during the Quaternary by weathering, leaching and erosional processes. These 90
geological controls explain the presence of these structures in the Paraná volcanic 91
province and the lack of citation of these structures in other provinces in the world. 92
Because of the great economic significance of the geode deposits in the Ametista 93
do Sul district, we conducted a survey to identify the silica gossans and their 94
characteristics. We used mostly field mapping, field gamma spectrometry, petrography, 95
rock geochemistry, X-ray diffraction and electron microprobe analyses of minerals. The 96
integration of the data resulted in an advanced understanding of processes related to 97
silicia gossan formation for their use as prospective guides of additional deposits in the 98
Paraná volcanic province. 99
100
5
2. Regional Geology 101
The Lower Cretaceous Paraná volcanic province is the second largest province 102
in the world covering an extensive area in southern Brazil, Uruguay, eastern Paraguay 103
and northern Argentina. The thickness of the lava pile is correlated with the shape of the 104
Paraná Basin. In the southern and northern boundaries only a few meters (Almeida, 105
1986) of lava flows occur, whereas in the center near Cuiabá Paulista the thickness 106
reaches 1723 m in depth, with more than a hundred lava flows in the volcanic pile 107
(Hartmann, 2014). The total area covered by the volcanic rocks is around 917,000 km2 108
(Frank et al., 2009). The tholeiitic basalts represent the main chemical composition, 109
however basaltic andesite, dacite, rhyodacite, andesite, rhyolite and pyroclastic rocks 110
(Licht et al., 2012) also occur. These rocks were divided into a low-Ti (<2 wt. % TiO2) 111
and high-Ti (>2 wt. % TiO2) group (Bellieni et al., 1984; Mantovani et al., 1985). Based 112
on major and trace elements and ratio of elements, Peate et al. (1992) reclassified the 113
low-Ti group into Gramado, Esmeralda and Ribeira magma-types and the high-Ti group 114
into Pitanga, Paranapanema and Urubici magma-types. The intermediate-Ti group was 115
proposed by Nakamura et al. (2003) and includes the Ribeira and Paranapanema 116
magma-types. The high and low-Ti groups stayed with the remaining magma-types. 117
Studies conducted by Licht and Arioli (2012) reassessed this geochemical division and 118
suggested at least 12-16 chemical types. Initially the stratigraphy of the flows indicated 119
the presence of low-Ti lavas at the base, high-Ti lavas in the center and intermediate-Ti 120
lavas at the top; however with the evolution of the studies the intercalation of flows 121
does not follow this model in all cases (Hartmann, 2014). The amethyst-bearing geodes 122
in the Paraná volcanic province occur in the low-Ti, intermediate-Ti and high-Ti flows 123
(Duarte et al., 2009; Gilg et al., 2003; Hartmann et al., 2014a; Juchem, 2010, 2014; 124
Rosenstengel and Hartmann, 2012), and their occurrence was described in several 125
6
mining districts such as Ametista do Sul, Entre Rios and Chopinzinho in Brazil, Los 126
Catalanes in Uruguay and Wanda in Argentina. Studies developed in some of these 127
districts have characterized the geology of the host basalts and discussed the origin of 128
deposits. One theory of amethyst geode deposits was attributed to lava degasification, 129
suggesting temperatures of 1150 ºC for the formation of the cavities (Gilg et al., 2003; 130
Morteani et al., 2010; Proust and Fontaine, 2007; Scopel et al., 1990). A study of Sr 131
isotopes in celadonite (Gilg et al., 2003) indicated the beginning of filling of geodes at 132
20–30 Ma after basalt eruption (Gilg et al., 2014) and was originated by repeated 133
injections of low- temperature sedimentary brines from deeper levels of the Paraná 134
basin. The amethyst crystallization occurred at temperature between 40 - 80 °C (Gilg et 135
al., 2003, 2014). In a different way, a hydrothermal model was proposed (Duarte et al., 136
2009, 2011, 2014) based on the H1, H2 and H3 hydrothermal events (Hartmann, 2008, 137
2012a, 2012b). The authors suggested the rising of hydrothermal fluids (boiling water 138
and its vapor) with huge quantity of sand from the Botucatu Formation across the 139
basaltic flows. As a result of hydrothermal processes, cavities were formed initially by 140
ballooning (Hartmann et al., 2012d) followed by the epigenetic amethyst deposits 141
(Duarte et al., 2009, 2014). In the same process, the silicified hydrothermal structures 142
(sandstone dikes, sandstone layers and even hydrothermal breccia at the top of the 143
flows) were also formed. 144
In the study area of Mina do Museu, the amethyst geode deposits are hosted in 145
three different Pitanga type I (Gomes, 1996) high-Ti flows. From bottom to the top they 146
are the Veia Baixa (~30 m tick), Veia do Meio (~20 m thick) and Veia Alta flow (~25 m 147
thick) flows. The Veia Alta flow is the main amethyst producer in the district. The 148
Coogamai flow is a barren Paranapanema intermediate-Ti flow and occurs above the 149
Veia Alta flow. The Coogamai flow has type II core and cooling joints. The thickness of 150
7
this flow at the Mina do Museu area is 35 m but its top was eroded. However the 151
Coogamai flow shows larger thicknesses in other areas of the mining district. Coogamai 152
is the uppermost flow in the Mina do Museu section and displays the presence of silica 153
gossan similar to descriptions in the Quaraí-Artigas mining district (Pertille et al., 2013) 154
and other places (e.g., Gramado, RS) along the Paraná province (Baggio et al., 2014). 155
The hydrothermal alteration and the weathering processes generated these structures 156
over the amethyst deposits. The satellite image from Mina do Museu silica gossan 157
displays a geometric structure and the different geological characteristics of the 158
amethyst geode deposit. Studies on silica gossan were applied in the municipality of 159
Quaraí, RS for the indication of preferred areas for exploration of amethyst geode 160
deposits (Hartmann et al., 2014b). 161
162
3. Methodology 163
The study developed in the Ametista do Sul mining district was focused in the 164
Mina do Museu, an exhausted amethyst mine turned into a museum that still retains 165
amethyst geodes in the host basalt galleries. The genetic model assumed in this study is 166
that described by Duarte et al. (2009, 2011, 2014). Several areas in the surroundings 167
were visited aiming at the comparison between them. Two volcanic flows were 168
evaluated, the Coogamai flow with the silica gossan and the Veia Alta flow, amethyst 169
producer. The Coogamai flow is the target of this study while Veia Alta flow was used 170
for geochemical, petrographic and gamma spectrometric comparison. The applied 171
methodology included the assessment of altimetry and geographic coordinates with a 172
Garmin portable GPS (Datum WGS84), description of rock outcrops and sample 173
collection in the Coogamai flow (n=10) and Veia Alta flow (n=9). Two of the samples 174
8
from Coogamai flow (A3A and A1) were previously published by Rosenstengel and 175
Hartmann (2012) and used in this study for geochemical comparison. 176
The petrographic description and optical images were performed in a Zeiss 177
axioplan microscope with ProgRes Jenoptik C10 digital photographic device. The 178
chemical analyses of the bulk samples were performed by ACME Analytical 179
laboratories, Vancouver, Canada for whole rock major and trace elements. The method 180
for elemental analyses was ICP (Inductively Coupled Plasma). For major elements the 181
method comprises melting of 0.1 g sample in metaborate / lithium tetraborate and 182
dilution with nitric digestion. The loss on ignition is obtained from the weight 183
difference after combustion at 1000 °C. Trace elements and rare earths are analyzed by 184
ICP-MS (mass spectrometry), following the same procedure of the major elements with 185
the addition of 0.5 g sample digested in aqua regia for analysis by ICP-MS. 186
For the gamma spectrometry survey in the Coogamai flow and Veia Alta flow, 187
two different field techniques were used. The first included the readings of the gamma 188
spectrometry in surface sections over the Coogamai and Veia Alta flows (heterogeneous 189
material including soil, altered and fresh rocks) and the second was made exclusively in 190
the Veia Alta flow through an old gallery of amethyst extraction in the Mina do Museu. 191
The devices used were the Exploranium GR110 scintillometer (measurement time 10 s) 192
and RS-125 Gamma spectrometer (measurement time 60 s) with NaI detector crystal. 193
The size of NaI crystal is 74 cm3 and 103 cm3 respectively. The readings of GR-110 194
display lower values (in counts per second, cps), but are equivalent to the measurements 195
of the RS-125 which allowed managing the work and testing the similarity of the 196
responses. The GR-110 was used to record the total counting of gamma radiation from 197
the rocks and the RS-125 was used for evaluation of the contents and distribution of 198
each radionuclide, %K (mean percent potassium), eU (equivalent uranium in parts per 199
9
million, ppm) and eTh (equivalent thorium in ppm). The values presented in this study 200
represent the average of 5 measurements in each station. The data were used to generate 201
a cps gamma spectrometric contour map with the software Oasis Montaj® (Geosoft 202
Latinoamerica) and also for the graphs of total cps using the Excel® software. 203
X-ray diffraction was performed to identify the clay minerals present in the soil 204
at the surface of the Mina do Museu silica gossan. The clay samples were prepared with 205
particle size smaller than 4 µm. The preparation and separation of this fraction involves 206
quartering the sample, crushing in porcelain mortar. After addition of deionized water, 207
the samples were stirred for 24 h in an orbital shaker and treated with an ultrasound 208
probe during 5 minutes. The settling time for the fraction<4 µm in a water column was 209
set according Stokes’ law at constant temperature. The fractions<4 µm sample fractions 210
were prepared on three glass slides with preferred (001) orientation of the clay minerals. 211
The glass slide 1 was prepared to air dry at room temperature. An oriented glycol 212
preparation was saturated with ethylene glycol to verify the presence of expansive clay 213
mineral, and the third glass slide was heated at 550 °C for 2 h (calcined) to test for clay 214
collapse under these conditions. The equipment used is a BRUKER AXS diffractometer 215
SIEMENS Model D5000 with 2? goniometer of Universidade Federal do Rio Grande 216
do Sul. The radiation was copper K? produced at 40 kV and 25 mA. The speed and 217
range of the goniometer scan for oriented samples were 2-3 s/0.02° 2? in the range of 3° 218
to 28° 2?. 219
The mineral compositions were measured with an wavelenght-dispersive 220
electron microprobe Cameca SX100 at Institute für Mineralogie und Kristalchemie of 221
Universität Stuttgart, Germany. The routine measurement protocol used for silicates 222
was 15 kV accelerating voltage, 15 nA beam current and focused beam. For clay 223
minerals, a lower beam current of 10 nA and larger beam size of 10 µm were applied. In 224
10
addition to the EMP investigation, back-scattered electron images and compositional 225
maps of Mg, Al, Fe, Ca and Na were made to evaluate the compositional variation of 226
smectite in different structural sites. Mineral formulae have been calculated with the 227
Microsoft Excel based CalcMin software (Brandelik & Massonne 2004). 228
229
4. Results 230
Several basalt flows were mapped in the Ametista do Sul mining district (Fig. 231
2A) with the Mina do Museu area located in the center of the district; previous flow 232
stratigraphy was determined by Rosenstengel and Hartmann (2012). The recognized 233
flows are the A5 flow, Veia Baixa flow, Veia do Meio flow, Veia Alta and the 234
Coogamai flows from bottom to top of the hills (Fig. 2B). During field work, 235
hydrothermal breccias and silicified sandstone layers were also described; these are 236
small bodies, not located in Fig. 2. Several results are now described, including the 237
petrography, rock geochemistry, gamma spectrometry, X-ray diffraction and electron 238
microprobe analyses. 239
240
4.1 Petrography 241
The primary minerals of Veia Alta and Coogamai flows is practically the same 242
and the main difference between flows is the occurrence of alteration minerals (clay 243
minerals) which is larger in the Veia alta flow. The Coogamai flow contains plagioclase 244
(44-48 vol.%), clinopyroxene (augite and pigeonite, 23-27%), opaque minerals 245
(magnetite and ilmenite, 10-14%), microcrystalline matrix (quartz, plagioclase and K 246
feldspar, 5-9%), clay minerals (smectites, 2-8%) and traces of apatite. Samples LF1 and 247
LQ1 are located outside of the silica gossan and display holocrystalline texture with 248
microphenocrysts of plagioclase. The main texture is intergranular but in some places 249
11
glomeroporphyritic. The intergranular texture is formed by subhedral to euhedral 250
elongated prisms of plagioclase phenocrysts (0.1-0.3 mm-size) associated with 251
subhedral to anhedral crystals (?0,2 mm) of clinopyroxene and rounded to subhedral 252
crystals (?0,2 mm) of magnetite – ilmenite. The glomeroporphyritic texture is formed 253
mainly by plagioclase crystals surrounded by opaque minerals. In some areas, the 254
plagioclase crystals reach up to 0.5 mm in size. Apatite is an accessory mineral and 255
occurs as fine needle-shaped crystals. The samples B1, MM90 and MM95 within the 256
silica gossan, shows a holocrystalline and microporphyritic texture. The content of 257
smectite outside silica gossan (Fig. 3A, B) is comparatively less than within silica 258
gossan. The intergranular texture is formed by subhedral to euhedral elongated 259
plagioclase crystals (0.2-0.4 mm) in association of anhedral to euhedral clinopyroxene 260
crystals (0.1-0.3 mm) and rounded opaque minerals (0.1-0.3mm). In some places, 261
microphenocrysts (0.5-0.7 mm) of opaque minerals with skeletal habit are observed. 262
The partial alteration of magnetite and clinopyroxene is highlighted by areas with red 263
and brown stains surrounding the crystals and also in the extreme cases with formation 264
of smectites with 0.5-0.8 mm size within silica gossan (Fig. 3C, D). 265
The Veia Alta flow is composed of plagioclase (36-40 vol.%), clinopyroxene 266
(18-24 %), opaque minerals (8-13 %), microcrystalline matrix (2-7 %), clay minerals 267
(20-30 %) and traces of apatite. The basalt is holocrystalline and microporphyritic with 268
intergranular texture and microcrystalline matrix. The elongated plagioclase 269
phenocrysts are euhedral to subhedral (up to 0.7 mm size) and the clinopyroxene 270
phenocrysts are present in minor amounts. The intergranular texture is composed of 271
subhedral to euhedral plagioclase crystals (0.2 - 0.5 mm). The subhedral clinopyroxene 272
crystals are small (0.1-0.4 mm) and often with partial alteration in the rims. The opaque 273
minerals show platy shape (up to 0.9 mm size) and also lozenge subhedral crystals (0.1 274
12
– 0.4 mm). The microcrystalline matrix presents quartz, plagioclase and KF in the 275
interstices forming intersertal texture and has areas altered to clay minerals. Apatite is a 276
needle-shaped accessory mineral. In the Veia Alta flow the formation of smectites 277
(brown to orange color) are widely distributed and the presence of celadonite (green 278
pockets) was observed only in this amethyst mineralized flow (Fig. 3E, F). 279
280
4.2 Rock geochemistry 281
The analyzed samples from the Ametista do Sul mining district represent the 282
Coogamai flow (both outside and within Mina do Museu Silica gossan) and the Veia 283
Alta flow. The location and chemical analyses are available in Tables 1 and 2. 284
Both lava flows are classified as basalt according to the total alkalis-silica (TAS) 285
diagram (Fig. 4A; Cox et al., 1979). The Coogamai flow plots in the intermediate-Ti 286
group (Nakamura et al., 2003) as a Paranapanema magma type (Peate et al., 1992, 1997, 287
1999) with TiO2 content ranging from 2.23 - 2.34 wt.% and P2O5 contents from 0.27 - 288
0.29 wt.% (Fig. 4B, C). The Veia Alta flow belongs to the high-Ti group and displays 289
Pitanga magma-type (Peate et al., 1992). TiO2 content varies from 3.54 - 3.76 wt.% and 290
P2O5 contents range from 0.52 - 0.57 wt.% (Fig. 4B, C). The identification and 291
individualization of the magma-types is observed also from the distribution of TiO2 and 292
P2O5 contents and low-mobility elements Th, Hf, Nb, Y, Pr, Ce, Ta, La and Zr. 293
Several studies conducted in the southern portion of the Paraná volcanic 294
province (e.g., Duarte et al., 2009; Hartmann, 2008; Hartmann et al., 2010, 2012a, 2015; 295
Meunier et al., 1988; Pinto et al., 2011b; Rosenstengel and Hartmann, 2012) highlighted 296
the concept of the amethyst-bearing geodes genesis based on a hydrothermal model. For 297
instance, in the Veia Alta and Coogamai flows the hydrothermal alteration, represented 298
by LOI is the main parameter for evaluation of the volcanic rocks and an important 299
13
amethyst prospective guide. The LOI and SiO2 contents show negative correlation in 300
both flows (Fig. 4D). The SiO2 content for Coogamai flow ranges from 47.43 wt.% to 301
49.87 wt.% and the LOI varies from 0.2 to 0.5 wt. % for samples outside silica gossan 302
and 0.9 wt.% to 1.8 wt.% for samples within silica gossan. In the Veia Alta flow, the 303
SiO2 variation is between 46.38 wt.% and 50.54 wt.% and the LOI ranges from 3.1 304
wt.% to 5.2 wt.% showing the expected correlation between hydrothermal alteration and 305
the geode deposits origin (Duarte et al., 2009). However some studies (e.g., Duarte et 306
al., 2011; Hartmann et al., 2010; Pertille et al., 2013; Rosenstengel and Hartmann, 307
2012) suggested that the hydrothermal alteration indicated by the LOI (>2 wt. %) can 308
limit the reliability of the classification of the volcanic rocks, especially in cases where 309
the separation of the flows uses small variations in the TiO2 and P2O5 content and 310
immobile trace elements (e.g., Zr and Hf). In this study, this restriction does not apply 311
because the study focuses on only two, geochemically distinct flows. Furthermore, in 312
the case of Veia Alta flow there is a strong field control across the amethyst gallery and 313
also the gamma spectrometry, allowing confirm the stratigraphic position and chemical 314
characteristics of each flow in the district. 315
The evaluation of the LOI indicates a gradual transition between areas with 316
silica gossan and areas without such alteration. The negative correlation with LOI and 317
the contents of SiO2, K2O (Fig. 5A), Rb and U are similar to the observations by Pertille 318
et al. (2013) in gossans of Quaraí-Artigas region. Additionally, in the Mina do Museu 319
silica gossan, a negative correlation of LOI was observed with the contents of MgO 320
(Fig. 5B), CaO (Fig. 5C) and Na2O (Fig. 5D). Despite of the increase in LOI, some 321
elements such as Th, Ta, Tb and Sc remain almost unmodified outside and within the 322
silica gossan. 323

4.3 Gamma spectrometry 325
Gamma spectrometric measurements decode the radiometric signature of the 326
flows as demonstrated in recent studies (e.g. Hartmann et al., 2010, 2012b; Pertille et 327
al., 2013). In the Ametista do Sul mining district, this tool was used by Rosenstengel 328
and Hartmann (2012) to separate the basaltic flows. 329
The gamma spectrometry signature of the flows in the Mina do Museu silica 330
gossan (Fig. 6A) confirms that the Pitanga basaltic flows show higher counts per second 331
than Paranapanema basaltic flow (Table 3). Two field sections were made in the gamma 332
spectrometric survey. The first was performed at the surface of volcanic flows near the 333
silica gossan of the Coogamai (Fig. 6B) and Veia Alta flows (Fig. 6C). The second was 334
made through one gallery in the Mina do Museu across the entire width of the mountain 335
in the mineralized Veia Alta flow. The result of the first section showed that the Veia 336
Alta flow gamma spectrometry average is 85 cps (GR-110), equivalent to 107 cps in the 337
readings of RS-125 and very close to the regional gamma spectrometric average 338
described by Rosenstengel and Hartmann (2012). The gamma spectrometry profile on 339
the Mina do Museu and surroundings of the Coogamai flow allows the identification of 340
negative anomalous areas at the site of the silica gossan. 341
The gamma spectrometric data of several profiles results in a map (Fig. 6D) that 342
shows the progression of negative anomalies from the rim to the core of the structure 343
with the lowest values on the amethyst deposits, whereas in areas without amethyst 344
deposits the values are close to the average of Coogamai flow (55 cps, GR-110). The 345
distribution of the radionuclides eTh, eU and %K (Table 4) in the surface sections show 346
the same negative anomalies in the Coogamai flow. The values show variation in the 347
contents of radionuclides in both flows mainly in eU and eTh while the %K shows 348
values with less variation. 349

4.4 X-Ray diffraction 351
The use of X-ray diffraction leads to the identification of clay minerals present 352
in the Mina do Museu silica gossan. The survey section (A1T1A=0.95m) performed for 353
a palynological study (Gadens-Marcon et al., 2014) was used also in this study. This 354
survey section included the variation from top to the bottom of the section. At the top 355
there is a grayish organic soil (0.0m – 0.15m) followed by a very plastic dark gray clay 356
(0.15 m – 0.65 m) and at the end of the section an intensely altered basalt (0.65 m – 0.95 357
m) with concentration of iron oxides (e.g. goethite) with brownish to ocher color. The 358
X-ray diffraction (Fig. 7) was performed using oriented clays method under natural 359
condition, glycol and calcinated at 550 ºC. The evaluation of the results was based on 360
the peak intensity and behavior of the interplanar distances that identify montmorillonite 361
and kaolinite. Montmorillonite shows a pattern identified by the interplanar distance of 362
14.66 Å under natural oriented condition. Under the condition of oriented glycol the 363
interplanar distance was modified to 17.12 Å due to its expandability property. When 364
subjected to heating at 550 ºC the interplanar distance increased to 10.15 Å which 365
confirmed the montmorillonite identification. In the same way, the kaolinite also 366
presented its standard behavior from the peaks of intensity that characterize the 367
interplanar distances of 7.17 Å and 3.57 Å (natural and glycol) and collapsing of the 368
structure when subjected to 550 ºC. 369

Mina do Museu silica gossan (Fig. 8A, B, C, D). The most significant difference was 374

clinopyroxene, magnetite and ilmenite. The compositional range of clinopyroxene and 376

The clinopyroxene from Coogamai flow occurs in the matrix and as 390

composition in the Coogamai flow presents a global variation from Wo31-44. In the 392

silica gossan is Wo7-15 (Fig 8F). The clinopyroxene crystals usually display alteration 395
and in some places are replaced by smectite. 396
The presence of smectite in the samples outside silica gossan is limited to a few 397
crystals while in samples within the silica gossan the presence of clay minerals is more 398
extensive. Representative EMPA analyses of smectite from the Coogamai flow are in 399

Table 7. The Si and K show positive correlation (Fig. 8G). The highest contents occur 400

gossan whereas Mg has an inverse distribution. Ca in the Coogamai flow displays a 402

5. Discussion 420
The Mina do Museu silica gossan is an example of prospective guide of 421
amethyst geode deposits in the Ametista do Sul mining district. Differently from the 422
gossans originated from sulphide mineralization, the Mina do Museu silica gossan was 423
generated in a very low sulphide environment. The denomination silica gossan (e.g., 424
18
Keller and Hanson, 1968; Sayin, 2007) was used to describe prospective guides of 425
kaolin deposits in volcanic rocks in Mexico and Turkey. The authors highlight the 426
oxidized iron-rich zone, color change on the silica gossan surface, presence of kaolinite 427
and chalcedony infilling cavities. 428
In the Serra Geral Group, Hartmann (2008) identified for the first time gossans 429
on top of the deposits of amethyst and agate in basalts and rhyodacites. The evolution of 430
this matter made Pertille et al. (2013) promote the major advance in understanding of 431
these amethyst prospective guides. The study in the Los Catalanes (Uruguay) and 432
Quarai (Brazil) mining district described gossans in the same amethyst host flow on the 433
two sides of the border. The origin of the gossans was correlated to the H1, H2 and H3 434
hydrothermal events (Hartmann 2008, 2010). The Cretaceous volcanism was the heat 435
source that affected the Guarani aquifer and generated the low salinity hydrothermal 436
fluids at temperatures below 150 ºC. The pressure exerted by the boiling water and its 437
vapor raised fluidized sand (30 vol.% in water) from the Botucatu Formation and left 438
the sand as residue forming structures such as sills and dikes of sandstone along the path 439
of the hydrothermal fluid. As time passed and the process continued active, the sand of 440
these structures was silicified by the hydrothermal fluids while the amethysts were 441
deposited within the cavities generated in the H3 event. The oxidation of clinopyroxene 442
and opaque minerals of Coogamai flow provided a large amount of free iron oxides 443
highlighting reddish to brownish spots and formation of smectite, consistent with the 444
low-temperature hydrothermal alteration (Duarte et al., 2009, 2011; Hartmann, 2008; 445
Hartmann et al., 2010, 2012c, 2012d; Pinto et al., 2011b). 446
Supergene processes in the Quaternary began to act at the surface, changing and 447
leaching elements and eroding the Coogamai flow. However, the presence of silicified 448
structures close to the amethyst geodes deposit turned these areas more resistant to 449
19
erosion. The concentration of iron-rich crusts turned the surface ocher to brownish color 450
with development of marshes and sometimes lakes. Over the amethyst deposits, the 451
supergene alteration caused oxidation, formation of soil, clay minerals (montmorilonite 452
and kaolinite), and silica gossans. Therefore, the Mina do Museu silica gossan is the 453
result of the superposition of hydrothermal alteration of basalts added by silicification 454
of sand layers brought up by H1, H2 and H3 and weathering processes. 455
The Veia Alta and Coogamai flows in the Ametista do Sul mining disctrict 456
virtually display the same primary mineral composition. However the hydrothermal 457
activity and the composition of the fluid phase on these flows promoted the formation 458
of clay minerals with different composition. In the Veia Alta flow were formed smectite 459
and celadonite and in the Coogamai flow only smectite was observed. The smectite has 460
weak chemical bonds and high cation exchange capacity and soluble elements tend to 461
be released from the host primary minerals by hydrothermal fluids.The composition of 462
smectite in both flows is characterized by a very low Al content. In most cases, there is 463
not sufficient Al to fill, together with Si, the tetrahedral position, and ferric iron is 464
entering into this position. Accordingly, the octahedral position does not contain Al and 465
is composed of Mg and Fe. Interlayer cations comprise Ca, Na, and K. Fe and Mg may 466
be additionally present in the interlayer. Particularly, in the Coogamai flow, the 467
chemical analyzes of whole rock demonstrates that the SiO2 and Al2O3 contents in most 468
cases are higher outside silica gossan than inside silica gossan showing a positive 469
correlation. Also, the Al2O3 x Fe2O3 and SiO2 x Fe2O3 display slightly negative 470
correlations. Thus, the hydrothermal fluid path across the Coogamai flow generated 471
different smectite outside and within silica gossan. Outside silica gossan smectite are 472
characterized by relatively low octahedral totals of 2.7 to 2.2 p.f.u., and relatively high 473
interlayer totals (Ca+Na+K) of 0.3 to 0.5 p.f.u., which approaches to dioctahedral 474
20
member. In contrast, within silica gossan smectite has higher tetrahedral total of 2.5 to 475
2.9 p.f.u., and distinctly lower interlayer totals (Ca+Na+K) of 0.2 to 0.3 p.f.u., close to a 476
trioctahedral member. Relatively the low hydrothermal activity outside silica gossan is 477
characterized by dioctahedral smectite with an interlayer dominated by K derived from 478
K feldspar from interstitial matrix. The incipient alteration of the basalt starts in the 479
fine-grained portions and is characterized by a large interface surface. This 480
interpretation is also supported by the lower K content in microcrystalline sanidine 481
inside the silica gossan. On the other hand in the more heavily altered basalt, the 482
decomposition of clinopyroxene and of Fe oxides delivered Fe and Mg to the fluid 483
phase. Smectite formed in equilibrium with that hydrothermal fluid is accordingly richer 484
in these elements. The ratio Ca/Ca+K+Na in smectite from silica gossan also indicate a 485
Ca richer source of the fluid phase from which smectite is precipitated. In the Coogamai 486
flow, in addition to the smectite was also observed the presence of kaolinite. The 487
contrast between environmental conditions of formation of smectite and kaolinite was 488
studied by Keller (1964). Smectite is formed in chemical environments characterized by 489
high Si/Al ratio associated with the availability of elements such as Mg, Na, Fe, Ca and 490
K and low concentration of H ions, and depends of the local climate conditions and also 491
of the soil permeability and drainage. Humid climates associated with areas with low 492
permeability or deficient drainage facilitates the concentration of soluble silica and 493
cations and the environment becomes conducive to the formation of smectite clay 494
minerals. If in these same kinds of climate, a high permeability or efficient drainage 495
occurs, then cations can be leached and silica placed in solution, so the environment 496
becomes conducive to the formation of kaolinite. 497
The study made in gossans in the Paraná volcanic province highlights the 498
presence of smectite within the gossans and the occurrence of gamma spectrometric 499
21
anomalies over the amethyst deposits. These features distinguish the gossan structure 500
from the other field sections. The same evidence was observed in several places (Baggio 501
et al., 2014) in the Paraná province (e.g., Entre Rios mining district) and confirmed the 502
gamma spectrometric variations and negative anomaly over the amethyst geode 503
deposits. In the Quaraí and Artigas mining districts, Pertille et al. (2013) indicated that 504
the gamma spectrometry readings are associated to the intense hydrothermal alteration, 505
represented by the LOI > 2 wt. %. LOI contents are negatively correlated with SiO2, 506
K2O, Rb contents and Rb/Sr ratios on the gossans. In these districts, the amethyst geode 507
deposits and the gossan occur in the same volcanic flow while in the Ametista do Sul 508
mining district, the Veia Alta flow (LOI average 4 wt.%) with the amethyst deposit 509
geodes is stratigraphically below the Coogamai flow that displays the silica gossan. This 510
flow with type II core is characterized by lower LOI ranging from 0.8 to 1.0 wt. %. This 511
evaluation leads to the reassessment of the interpretation of the gamma spectrometric 512
anomalies. Besides the hydrothermal alteration, the weathering process that highlighted 513
the silica gossan at the surface, interferes in the U, Th and K contents in the silica 514
gossans. The studies on Th and U mobility (Dickson and Scott, 1997; Dickson et al., 515
1996; Langmuir, 1980; Reiller et al., 2002) show the increase of mobility of these 516
elements in certain conditions. These elements freed by the breakdown of minerals 517
during weathering events are normally retained in Fe oxides-hydroxides, soluble 518
complexes silicates and/or colloidal clays and are transported absorbed by gravitational 519
processes (Dickson and Scott, 1997; Souza and Ferreira, 2005). The concentrations of 520
Fe (goethite and hematite) oxides-oxyhydroxides increase the Th solubility (Reiller et 521
al., 2002) and the U mobility. The deep alteration of pyroxene and opaque minerals 522
caused by hydrothermal fluids initiated the argillic alteration, oxidation and 523
concentration of Fe. The combination of these factors associated to weathering and 524
22
erosion events led to the development of physical and chemical conditions for the 525
leaching of the radionuclides Th and U absorbed in organic complexes, iron oxides and 526
soluble silicate complexes. The enrichment in iron is associated with decrease of Th and 527
U contents. The geochemical analyses of Th bulk rocks shows few changes in content 528
inside and outside the gossan silica in comparison with LOI, but the gamma 529
spectrometric readings show significant Th changes in the soil within the silica gossan 530
and outside silica gossan. A similar effect occurs with uranium. The U gamma 531
spectrometric readings show a larger difference between the areas with soil outside 532
silica gossan and within silica gossan. However, the primary comparison was observed 533
in potassium readings because the contents of K2O (bulk rock) display a negative 534
correlation with the LOI, with higher K2O contents in the samples outside silica gossan. 535
The gamma spectrometric readings confirm this distribution in all sections. 536
537
6. Conclusions 538
The Mina do Museu silica gossan is proposed as a prospective guide model for 539
amethyst geode deposit in the Paraná volcanic province. The Veia Alta flow is the main 540
amethyst producer in the district and displays very high values of LOI (~4 wt.%) and 541
gamma spectrometry average of 85 cps. The Coogamai flow with silica gossan exhibits 542
outside silica gossan contents of LOI of 0.2-0.5 wt.% and gamma spectrometry average 543
of 55 cps while in areas within silica gossan, on the amethyst deposits, the contents of 544
LOI varies 0.9-1.8 wt.% and the gamma spectrometry average is 43.5 cps. The presence 545
of gossans like Mina do Museu in an intraplate environment is based on the unique 546
geological features developed in the Paraná volcanic province, which explains the lack 547
of description of these structures in other provinces of the world. 548
23
The key features for discrimination of the Mina do Museu gossan model can be 549
separated in two groups. 1) Field features. Significant change in vegetation, marsh areas 550
with intense argillic alteration, silicified sand structures more resistant to erosion, iron-551
rich surface on the structure forming an oxidized zone with reddish brown or ocher 552
color. 2) Survey features. Geometric structure in satellite images, increase of LOI within 553
silica gossan and negative correlation between LOI and oxides (e.g., SiO2), presence of 554
negative anomalies of K, eU and eTh on the amethyst geode deposits and presence of 555
K-smectites outside silica gossan and Mg-smectites within the silica gossan that could 556
serve as a proxy for the degree of basalt alteration. 557

Basalt stratigraphy and silica gossans in Campo Grande and Serra de Maracaju, Mato Grosso do Sul, Paraná Volcanic Province
S.B. Baggio a, L.A. Hartmann a,?, R.H.P. Andrade b, G.J. Rizzotto c, S.K. Duarte a, D.B. Knijnik a, J.A. Simões-Neto b

Keywords:
Silica gossan Paraná volcanic province Hydrothermal deposits Volcanic stratigraphy Serra Geral group Geochemistry
Thousands of silica gossans are exposed at the top of the Lower Cretaceous basalt hills in the Paraná volcanic province, strongly indicating the presence of calcite, amethyst and agate geode deposits along with native copper mineralization. The Embrapa silica gossan in the northwestern portion of the province (Campo Grande region) is an excellent example of such novel geological structure in the continental flood basalts. This silica gossan has a size of 450 × 350 m standing out as a treeless area in the densely wooded savanna and makes part of the stratig- raphy of six basalt flows of Paranapanema intermediate-Ti chemical type. The base of the volcanic column is con- stituted by two Pitanga types and the overlying column is Paranapanema type. Every basalt flow has a silicified sand layer or breccia at the top and these are fed by abundant sand dikes. The Anel Viário Norte (AVN) flow is the most intensely altered by hydrothermal fluids producing voluminous secondary calcite infillings in the amygdales and fractures. In this region the basalts contain higher copper content than the average of the volcanic province. The studied silica gossans display negative anomalies in gamma spectrometry as a response to K, U and Th depletion during alteration. We propose a new exploration methodology by observing GoogleEarth images complemented with field studies and geochemistry to readily locate favorable areas for amethyst and agate geode deposits and native copper mineralization.

1. Introduction
The identification of silica gossans in the Paraná continental flood basalt (CFB) province (Fig. 1) of South America opens the possibility of the existence of many hitherto unsuspected hydrothermal deposits. Al- most every erosional remnant hill in the province seems to contain silica gossans. Gossans commonly occur above high-sulfidation ore deposits (Scott et al., 2001; Pirajno, 2009), but the low-sulfide gossans in the Paraná volcanic province are also enriched in goethite-limonite, clay minerals and silica (silicified sandstone dikes and sills). This leads to the use of the expression “silica gossan” as an adequate name for the geological structure resulting from supergene alteration of the hydro- thermal deposits. An extensive literature survey did not provide any ad- ditional information on silica gossans within continental basaltic provinces. This is thus a novel approach to a common geological struc- ture, because a low-sulfide intraplate volcanic province hosts many hy- drothermal deposits and associated silica gossans.
The earlier study of gossans in the southern part of the province (Pertille et al., 2013) is extended with the present investigation to the northwestern extreme of the Paraná basin. Because silica gossans in the Campo Grande region may contain unexplored deposits, the basalt stratigraphy is here established with the use of field description, gamma-spectrometry and rock geochemistry to adequately position the gossans in the host basalt flow.
2. Regional geology
The Paraná continental flood basalt (CFB) province of South America is one of the largest igneous provinces in the world and covers an area of 917,000 km2 (Frank et al., 2009) in Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina and Paraguay (Fig. 1) with a lava volume of 450,000 km3 at the surface in ad- dition to 112,000 km3 of lava that remained in the subsurface as sills and dikes. The Cuiabá Paulista borehole suggests the total thickness of the volcanic pile to be 1723 m. To the south, the lava pile becomes progres- sively thinner reaching 50 m along the Brazil–Argentina border (Almeida, 1986). The thickness of individual flows (Peate et al., 1999) is 5 to 80 m, with an average of 20 m. Although the most abundant rocks are basalt and basaltic andesite, dacites, rhyodacites and rhyolites do occur in the upper part of the volcanic pile in the southern portion of

The volcanic rocks constitute the Serra Geral Group in Brazil (Wildner et al., 2009). The age of the group is under debate (e.g., Mantovani et al., 1985; Rocha-Campos et al., 1988; Mincato, 2000; Lustrino et al., 2005; Wildner et al., 2006) and recent studies (Pinto et al., 2011a, zircon U–Pb SHRIMP; Janasi et al., 2011, baddeleyite TIMS) confirmed the age of 133–135 Ma for the peak of volcanism. The geochemical subdivision of the Serra Geral Group was made based on the TiO2 content of the rocks (Bellieni et al., 1984; Mantovani et al.,
1985) into high-Ti (TiO2 N2%) in the north and low-Ti (TiO2 b2%) in the south. Peate et al. (1992) reassessed these two groups and proposed a new classification based on major and trace elements and element ra- tios. The low-Ti group was divided into Gramado, Esmeralda and Ribeira magma types and the high-Ti group into Urubici, Pitanga and Paranapanema magma types. The world's largest deposits of amethyst and agate are hosted in rocks from the two magma types. The main ex- ploration areas are concentrated in Ametista do Sul in Brazil and Los Catalanes in Uruguay (Juchem et al., 2010; Silva, 2010). Native copper mineralization hosted in basalts and in hydrothermal breccias is also widespread.
Until recently, the Serra Geral Group was studied mostly with re- spect to magmatic interactions (temperatures around 1150 °C), but from 2005 a new aspect of the Serra Geral Group was evaluated (e.g. Duarte et al., 2009; Hartmann et al., 2010, 2012a, 2012b; Pinto et al., 2011b) with the identification of low temperature hydrothermal events (150 °C). This new approach to studies of the Serra Geral Group allowed the understanding of a set of unique geological features such as the heat source, the water source in the Guarani aquifer, the unconsolidated sands of the Botucatu desert, the type I basalt flows (Gomes, 1996) and the intraplate tectonic environment (horizontal lavas). The combi- nation of these factors triggered intense hydrothermal events defined as H1, H2 and H3 (Hartmann, 2008; Hartmann et al., 2012a, 2012b) which were responsible for the rising of hydrothermal fluids (boiling water and its vapor) that transported upward through the basalt flows a huge quantity of sand from the Botucatu Formation. Evidence of the injected sand is widespread in several areas of the province (Hartmann et al, 2013) forming silicified hydrothermal structures as sand dikes, sand sills, sand layers and even hydrothermal breccia at

The hydrothermal alteration modi- fied the volcanic rocks, transforming pyroxenes and opaque minerals into clay minerals, mostly smectites and zeolites. The hydrothermal deposits associated with these events correspond to the largest amethyst-agate geode deposits in the world (Hartmann, 2008; Duarte et al., 2011; Rosenstengel and Hartmann, 2012) and also resulted in the formation of native copper mineralization (Pinto et al., 2011b). The silicified structures and their association with hydrothermal de- posits are observed in the entire stratigraphy of the volcanic pile from less than 50 m thick to the top of the sequence at 1000 m elevation.
In the Campo Grande region (Fig. 2), the little-studied basaltic rocks from the Serra Geral Group display a thickness of about 100 to 300 m (Lastoria, 2002). A reconnaissance study (Machado et al., 2009), however, indicated the predominance of high-Ti basalts of the Pitanga type. The volcanic rocks are nearly horizontal which extend for large distances and are cut by large vertical faults. The Campo Grande is at an elevation of 600 m, whereas the top of the Serra de Maracaju is at 500 m. The low-lying sedimentary plain in front of the cuesta is at 350 m (Campo Grande) and 250 m (Maracaju). The
thickness of the basalt group is therefore nearly 250 m in the entire pla- teau of the region. Classical geomorphological features are present, be- cause the present surface is more steeply inclined at the flow cores than in their contacts. Many polygonal or irregular areas display no trees on top of the basalt hills in the savanna of the region, so we select- ed a few of these structures for detailed investigations.
3. Methodology
The areas chosen for this study are from Campo Grande and Serra de Maracaju, Mato Grosso do Sul state. The methodology used for basalt stratigraphy and description of silica gossans involved the observation of anomalies in GoogleEarth images, field investigations including mea- surement of gamma-spectrometry emission rates, collection of repre- sentative rock samples and their chemical analyses. Two drill cores in the Campo Grande region and two sections in the Sidrolândia region were also sampled and studied. The gamma spectrometry evaluation of the Embrapa silica gossan was performed on a regular grid of 50 × 50 m (77 stations, 5 gamma- spectrometry readings at each station) covering an area of 550 × 450 m. In the Maracaju silica gossan we surveyed longitudinal sections that include the gossans and their immediate surroundings. The radiometric maps of gamma spectrometry were generated with software Oasis Montaj ® (Geosoft Latinoamerica) and the longitudinal section was calculated and drawn with the use of Excel and CorelDraw software.
Bulk rock samples from the Campo Grande region (n = 22) and from the Serra de Maracaju (n = 3) were chemically analyzed (Tables 1 and 2) at the ACME Analytical Laboratories, Vancouver, Canada for major and trace elements. The method used for the major elements comprises melting of 0.1 g sample in metaborate/lithium tetraborate and dilution with nitric digestion. Loss on ignition is obtained from the weight differ- ence after combustion at 1000 °C. Trace elements and rare earth ele- ments were analyzed by ICP–MS (mass spectrometry) following the same procedure of the major elements with the addition of 0.5 g sample
digested in aqua regia for analysis by ICP–MS. The data were integrated in Excel spread sheets and interpreted with the support of Geochemical Data Toolkit freeware (GCDKit).
Soil samples (n = 2) in Embrapa (S6D) and Serra de Maracaju (S7B) were collected inside the structure of silica gossans. These samples were grinded and sieved following standard procedures and aiming to iden- tify the mineralogy by X-ray diffraction (XRD). Each prepared powder was placed in a sample holder and the analyses of XRD were performed. For the confirmation of the identification of clay minerals, the b4 ?m fraction was used in oriented natural, oriented glycol and oriented calci- nated (550 °C) thin sections. XRD were carried out in a Siemens Bruker- AXS D5000 diffractometer with 2? goniometer, radiation K?l copper tube under conditions of 40 kV and 25 mA. The speed and the interval scanning of the goniometer for each type of analysis were as follows. Powder samples: 2 s to 0.02 of step goniometer 2? 2° to 72°. Oriented natural samples: 2 s to 0.02 for the second step of the goniometer 2? 2° to 28°. Oriented glycol samples: 3 s to 0.02 for the second step of the goniometer 2? 2° to 28°. 4. Silica gossans
Our usage of “silica gossan” finds support in previous studies. The ex- pression has been applied to prospective guides of hydrothermal kaolin deposits hosted either in Lower Tertiary rhyolites in San Luis Potosi, Mexico (Keller and Hanson, 1968) or in Lower Miocene andesites, dacites and tuffs in Turkey (Sayin, 2007). The main characteristics of these prospective guides are intense silicification, formation of oxidized iron-rich zones and change of color on the surface.
Studies carried out in Quaraí (Brazil) and Artigas (Uruguay) in basal- tic andesites showed the occurrence of gossans not related to sulfides in an intraplate continental environment (Pertille et al., 2013). Silica gos- sans register the presence of channelized hydrothermal deposits. The deposits are either silica minerals (also calcite) or native copper. The or- igin of silica is associated with the H2 and H3 events (Hartmann et al., 2010) that promoted the formation of veins, dikes and sills of silicified sand. The subsequent silicification of these bodies, in the Lower Creta- ceous, was generated by the boiling fluids (150 °C) derived from the Guarani aquifer along hydrothermal chimneys. In many parts of the Serra Geral Group, the silicification was very intense and made free sil- ica available for the formation of agate and amethyst deposits.
Quaternary weathering (Hartmann et al, 2010) led to the intense al- teration of the volcanic rocks. In amethyst-agate deposits and native copper mineralization, the supergene alteration caused oxidation, for- mation of clay minerals, soil and silica gossans. Therefore, a silica gossan is the result of the superposition of hydrothermal alteration of basalts with silicification and weathering. The altered volcanic flows display de- pletion in the content of some chemical elements including silica. Soils in the gossan are enriched in clay minerals with concentration of iron oxides and modification of the gamma spectrometry readings.
The evidence observed in the Campo Grande region and Serra de Maracaju is similar to the mining districts of Los Catalanes (Duarte et al., 2009, 2011), Ametista do Sul (Rosenstengel and Hartmann, 2012) and Entre Rios (Antunes et al., 2012; Hartmann et al., 2014) in the southern portion of the Paraná volcanic province.
5. Results
The fieldwork was directed to two targets. The first was focused in the local volcanic stratigraphy based in outcrops and quarries in the Campo Grande region and the second in the structures of silica gossans in the Campo Grande and Serra de Maracaju regions. The outcrops and quarries in the Campo Grande region (Fig. 3) are divided into sections designated AVN, Cascata Inferninho, rampa do Ernesto, São Luiz quarry, Campo Grande quarry (inactive, located in the São Francisco neighbor- hood of Campo Grande) and Votorantim quarry. The two Sidrolândia quarries are Negrimaq (active) and Quebra-Coco (inactive).
The AVN section (Fig. 4) has three lava flows, namely Abelha, AVN and Campo Grande. The São Luiz and Campo Grande quarries have ex- posures of the Campo Grande flow while the Abelha and AVN flows occur in the Cascata Inferninho and the Ernesto flow in the Ernesto sec- tion. The Votorantim quarry (Fig. 5) presents the AVN, Campo Grande, Pintado and Topo flows. In the Sidrolândia region (Fig. 6) the Quebra- Coco and Negrimaq quarries display the Campo Grande flow.
The six basaltic flows identified in this study show evidence of strong hydrothermal activity mainly at flow contacts. The hydrothermal events that generated these features resulted in varied gamma spec- trometry values along the stratigraphic profile because of the modifica- tion in geochemistry and mineralogy of the rocks. Weathering and erosion in these areas highlighted the silica gossan structures which are guides for low-temperature (150 °C) hydrothermal deposits. No rock outcrops were observed in the Embrapa silica gossan, whereas three outcrops were collected in the Serra de Maracaju gossan.
5.1. Basalt stratigraphy
The present study establishes the volcanic stratigraphy of the region, so that studied gossans can be placed in the respective lava flow. In the Campo Grande region, six basaltic flows are identified from gamma spectrometry in the field and also by chemical analyses. The basaltic flows were named from bottom to top as: (1) Ernesto, (2) Abelha, (3) AVN, (4) Campo Grande, (5) Pintado and (6) Topo.
The Ernesto flow is exposed at the base of the hill that has the rampa do Ernesto on top; it is somewhat altered with lozenge fracturing. The

gamma spectrometry average of the Ernesto flow is 57 cps (full data in Table 3). Silicified sand dikes and loose quartz and cornelian crystals occur in this site.
The Abelha flow (Fig. 4A and C) is basaltic in composition and occurs in the Anel Viário Norte road and in the Cascata Inferninho. The gamma spectrometry average of Abelha is 68 cps. Silicified sand dikes are more resistant to erosion than the altered basalt. Cavities are present in the amygdaloidal crust and small veins interconnected the cavities. The contact between the AVN and Abelha flows in the Cascata Inferninho is marked by hydrothermal breccia and silicified sand with a gamma spectrometry average of 69 cps.
The AVN flow (Fig. 4A, B and D) crops out in the Anel Viário Norte road and in the Cascata Inferninho. It is a basaltic rock with columnar jointing that is crossed by silicified sand dikes and displays horizontal veins with calcite deposition (Fig. 4D). Cooling joints are covered by thin (1 mm) films of fine-grained, reddish-colored sand in many places. The basalts are altered along curved planes into reddish minerals. The gamma spectrometry of AVN is 65 cps. The contact between the AVN and Campo Grande flows (Fig. 4B) has commonly hydrothermal breccia and silicified sand layers with a gamma spectrometry average of 80 cps.
The Campo Grande flow is of major geological and stratigraphic sig- nificance in the Campo Grande region, because it covers a large area and is intensely exploited for construction materials mostly crushed stone. It was described in several places, including the Anel Viário Norte (Fig. 4A, B and D) and the São Luiz, Campo Grande, Votorantim (Fig. 5A, B and C), Negrimaq and Quebra-Coco (Fig. 6A, B and C) quarries. The flow is dark gray basalt with vertical cooling joints and display gamma spectrometry average of 45 cps. The thickness of the Campo Grande flow reaches 30 m in the Votorantim quarry and the cooling joints present typically a thin, reddish film of fine sand and crosscutting silicified sand dikes. Horizon- tal calcite veins cross the silicified sand dikes and interconnect the cav- ities (volcanic amygdales and hydrothermal geodes). These correspond to hydrothermal events H1 and H2 (Hartmann, 2008); H1 is the filling of amygdales with calcite and H2 is the dissolution of calcite and filling of the same space with sand. The contact between the Campo Grande and Pintado flows (Votorantim quarry) is characterized by the presence of hydrothermal breccia and silicified sand with a gamma spectrometry average of 79 cps.
The Pintado flow was only described in the Votorantim quarry (Fig. 5A) as basalt with greenish gray color and a gamma spectrometry average of 35 cps. The contact between the Pintado and Topo flows (Votorantim quarry) is characterized by the presence of hydrothermal breccia with approximately 3 m thickness and silicified sand layer with 65 cps.
The uppermost flow observed (only in the Votorantim quarry) in the sequence is the Topo flow (Fig. 5A). This intensely altered basalt dis- plays a gamma spectrometry average of 29 cps; evidence of water infil- tration during weathering is the presence of soil blocks contained in hard rock.
The description of two drill cores (SR1 and SR4) (Fig. 7) supports the definition of the basalt stratigraphy. Three samples were collected from each core for chemical analyses. The Abelha, AVN and Campo Grande flows are present in the cores. Their relative positions confirm the infor- mation obtained from the outcrops.
5.2. Geochemistry
The lava flows in the Campo Grande region are all made up of basalts according to the total alkalis-silica (TAS) diagram (Fig. 8A) from Cox et al. (1979). The location of the analyzed samples is given in Table 4.
One of the geochemical characteristics is the intense hydrothermal alteration of the basalts in the Campo Grande region. The variation in the content of SiO2 is 46.38–51.25 wt.% and LOI from 1.3–6.1 wt.%. A strong negative correlation is observed between the SiO2 and LOI (Fig. 8B). The basalt magmas (Fig. 8C and D) in the region are
intermediate-Ti Paranapanema and high-Ti Pitanga types, based on Peate et al. (1992, 1999) and Peate (1997).
